awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Subject-level Prediction and Application
awd_abstract_narration:
Many practical problems are related to prediction, where the main interest is at the subject (for example personalized or precision medicine) or (small) sub-population (for example small community) level.  In recent years, new and challenging problems have emerged from diverse fields such as business, social sciences, and health sciences.  Examples may involve prediction of a health outcome for a new patient or perhaps prediction of a new school's response to efforts to educate children about smoking prevention.  The investigators have shown in previous work called classified mixed model prediction (CMMP) that in such cases, it is possible to make substantial gains in prediction accuracy by identifying a class that a new subject belongs to.  However, the scenarios under which CMMP currently operates are somewhat constrained and many real-life situations fall outside its scope.  Given the tremendous gains in accuracy that are possible, it would be very valuable to develop further methodology and computational advances to deepen knowledge in this area.    

This project aims to make methodological advances of the classified mixed model prediction method into other types of subject-level prediction problems as well as to develop new inferential methods along the CMMP idea, by making the latter truly useful in practical situations.  The basic idea of CMMP is to create a "match" between a group or cluster in the population for which one wishes to make prediction and a (massive) training dataset, with known groups or clusters. Once such a match is built, the traditional mixed model prediction method can be utilized to make accurate predictions. The practical challenges that will be solved in this project include i) how to deal with training data with unknown grouping; ii) how to deal with sparse, high dimensional covariates; iii) how to make better use of covariate information to improve accuracy of CMMP; and iv) how to provide accurate measures of uncertainty for CMMP-type predictions. Two important areas of application will be investigated.  One is in precision medicine and health disparities focusing on the prediction of epigenetic markers using high dimensional genotype profiles. The other comes from the area of family economics using a large survey of data from China where predictions at finer levels of resolution (e.g., households) are of primary interest. Both applications will leverage important collaborations with practitioners and thus increase the impact of the work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mixed model prediction (MMP) has a long history starting with Henderson's early work in animal breeding. The field has since flourished, thanks to its broad applications in various fields. The traditional fields of applications include genetics, agriculture, education, and surveys. This is a field where frequentist and Bayesian approaches found common grounds. Nowadays, new and challenging problems have emerged from such fields as business and health sciences, in addition to the traditional fields, to which methods of MMP are potentially applicable, but not without further methodology and computational developments. Some of these problems occur when interest is at subject level or (small) sub-population level, rather than at large population level. In such cases, it is possible to make substantial gains in prediction accuracy by identifying a class that a new subject belongs to. We have previously developed a new method, called classified mixed model prediction (CMMP), for making a better prediction by identifying the class to which the new subject belongs.

The new methods development we have done now filled some important gaps which make the methodology more applicable in practice.  Specifically, we have developed a more efficient CMMP method that incorporate prior information into the matching. This approach addresses the uncertainty in grouping, because the group index may be misclassified in CMMP. The proposed pseudo-Bayesian CMMP (PBCMMP) method improves the accuracy of matching and, as a result, the accuracy of mixed-effect prediction. What is more, a theoretical foundation has been built for the PBCMMP method regarding its asymptotic optimality in matching and prediction.

We have also carried out a theoretical study on the impact of misclassification of the group index in the analysis of linear mixed models, where maximum likelihood and restricted maximum likelihood are the standard methods to use.

Currently, more and more practical problems involving high dimensional data are moving beyond the variable selection framework to focus on prediction at the subject or (small) sub-population level.  Significant increases in prediction accuracy can be achieved by identifying a group that a new subject belongs to as was done in the Classified Mixed Model Prediction (CMMP) work of Jiang et al. (2018).  We developed a new method, called High Dimensional Classified Mixed Model Prediction (HDCMMP), which allows classified mixed predictions for high dimensional predictors with estimated grouping.  The methodology estimates the grouping of the observations, then a four-step algorithm follows, which includes a mixed model variable screening step, followed by penalized estimations of both fixed and random effects, followed by re-estimation for the restricted model, and followed by CMMP prediction. Asymptotic and empirical studies were carried out which demonstrated favorable properties of HDCMMP under the estimated grouping.   Finally, an analysis of riboflavin production data and breast cancer genomic data clearly demonstrated the utility of the new methodology in practice.

Furthermore, we have developed a method of estimating the mean squared prediction error (MSPE) of CMMP. The method is based on an idea proposed by one of the PIs in a recent work, known as Sumca, which may be regarded as a hybrid of the linearization method and re-sampling method for estimating the MSPE. The Sumca method was implemented successfully for CMMP, resulting accurate estimation of the MSPE. The performance of the proposed method is evaluated empirically.

Additionally, we have developed a new CMMP method that incorporates covariate information in the prediction. Not surprisingly, the method results in improvement in prediction accuracy when covariate information is used in the matching. The method has another advantage in that it does not require that outcome data are available for the new subjects. In other words, suppose only covariate information is available for the new subjects. With this new method, one can still carry out the CMMP procedure, unlike the original CMMP method which require that some outcome data are available for the new subjects.

Finally, we have extended the CMMP method to classified mixed model projection. It is known that projection is, in general, a more difficult problem than prediction due to lack of information in the training data for the projection group. We used a regrouping idea to divide the training data into two subsets, with one subset more similar to the projection group. This basic idea was executed successfully in the new method.

 It is expected to have major impact in statistical prediction theory and applications, especially in prediction based on mixed effects models.
